title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) – The Summit bore witness to a historic, singular force of nature Friday night. In a virtuoso performance for the ages, Houston Rockets superstar Hakeem Olajuwon delivered a game so dominant, so statistically staggering, it transcended the final score and etched itself into NBA lore.

Facing the Denver Nuggets, Olajuwon was simply unplayable. The Hall-of-Fame center poured in a career-high and franchise-record 51 points, a number that resonates with the authority of each one of his patented post moves. He was a whirlwind of offensive artistry, leaving a trail of defenders in his wake. But “The Dream” was far from a one-dimensional force; he corralled 18 rebounds, controlled the paint with five blocked shots, and even dished out three assists, a complete masterpiece in every sense.

While Clyde Drexler provided a crucial 21-point supporting role, this night belonged solely to Olajuwon. His 51 points were not just a personal best; they were a statement, a reminder of his peak powers during the twilight of a legendary career. The Denver Nuggets, despite a valiant 27-point effort from LaPhonso Ellis, had no answer. They were spectators to a legend writing his own chapter.

The final, 120-105, tells the story of a Rockets victory. But the true story, the one that will echo through time, is the night Hakeem Olajuwon scored half his team's points and reminded the basketball world of his boundless, dream-like genius.
